isis.stitle: TSI 93-17-01 - Hubcap for Oil Lubricated Wheel Bearing on Non-Driving Front Axles

subjectgroup.subject: Hubcap for Oil Lubricated Wheel Bearing on Non-Driving Front Axles

geninfo.para: This TSI applies to all models equipped with I-Beam Front Axles of 9,000 to 20,000 pounds capacity.
This letter contains information on the operation and maintenance International's hubcap ( Figure 1) used with oil lubricated front wheel bearings on 9,000 to 20,000 pound non-driving front axles.

svcproc.title: OPERATION
svcproc.para: During normal vehicle duty cycle, the lube and air inside the hub/wheel cavity expands, and if not vented causes pressure build up in the wheel cavity, resulting in accelerated seal wear. The rubber plug in the center of the hubcap face has a slit in it to allow the pressure in the hub/wheel cavity to be maintained in an operating range that is not detrimental to seal life. Navistar uses the slit type of venting as it allows less contamination (moisture, dust, etc.) to get into the hub/wheel cavity during normal duty cycle, including chassis cleaning operations. As the air and oil expand, an oil/air mist is expelled through the vent. It is normal for a slight film of oil to be present on the outside of the hubcap around the vent slit (or hole in the case of non-standard Navistar hubcaps.)

svcproc.title: MAINTENANCE
svcproc.para: Over a period of time, if the hubcap is not routinely cleaned, a slight film of oil can collect dirt around the rubber fill plug and face which could be perceived as a leak. Furthermore, routine cleaning ensures that the lube level can be easily observed through the clear window as intended.

note.para: Use caution when cleaning the hubcap with a high pressure cleaner as cleaning fluid, water and/or steam may be forced through the vent and contaminate the oil.

svcproc.para: In a case where the window is clear on the outside but discolored on the inside from the type of lubricant used, the lube level may be checked by removing the rubber check valve vent plug and inserting a finger through the hole in the face plate.
The specified lube level for clear window type hubcaps on International vehicles is from the minimum line to 5/16 inch above the minimum line.

If the lube level should suddenly drop below the minimum line between face wiping and lube level inspection intervals, it may serve as an indication of a leak somewhere in the system. If this should happen, take the following steps:

step1.para: Inspect the area around the gasket to determine if the gasket is leaking. A dry hubcap and a wet area around the gasket indicates the gasket could be leaking or the hubcap mounting bolts may be loose.
Check to be sure the mounting bolts are tight. Torque should be 16 to 20 ft. lbs.
Inspect for a leaking wheel seal.
Check the rubber vent for nicks or other damage that could cause leakage between the rubber plug and the outer edge of the plug opening.
If there is no apparent leakage, add same lube used in hub to raise level to minimum line Do not exceed 5/16 inch above the minimum line.
If these steps do not reveal leakage, the hubcap can be pressure checked to determine if it is leaking between the clear window and the aluminum body.
Remove the hubcap from vehicle and mount securely to a flat plate with silicone or similar sealer between the hubcap mounting surface and the plate.

note.para: It is best to remove the hubcap from the vehicle before pressure checking. Air pressure inside the hub could cause some wheel seals to move thus cause premature seal wear.

step1.para: Thoroughly clean the hubcap and the area around the mounting surface with a hot water/soap solution.
Remove the threaded fill plug in the side of the hubcap.
Screw an air line adapter into the fill plug hole. The standard International hubcap is tapped with 3/8-18 NPTF threads.
Connect a pressure regulator (1-10 PSI) and control valve to the adapter.
Apply a soap and water solution to entire hubcap body and around mounting flange.
Hold finger or thumb over slit in rubber check valve or hole in clear face.
SLOWLY open air valve and raise pressure to 10 PSI.
Check for air leaking between face and body or around rubber check vent and face. There should be no air escaping from these two potential leak paths.
If air escapes between face and body, discard the hubcap.
If air escapes between rubber check vent and face/body, inspect for damage to rubber check vent and/or face/body interface area.
Replace rubber check vent or hubcap if necessary.
